text: 'Cause I grew up in a family
where we weren’t allowed to swear
and I think that’s pretty common.
There’s not a lot of moms out there that are like,
“Just one F-word for mommy.
Just one. Hear it from your sweet little face.
From your face to my astonished face;
give me an F-word. Come on.
I mean, hit me with it."
It’s not a common thing.
But yeah,
we had the next level though, right.
In my family… like we didn’t say “Shut up,”
we said “shush up” to each other.
We were at that level.
“Shush up! ”
Sounds ridiculous, but I still don’t say “shut up".
I think it’s rude.
Who says “shut up?”
I’m still saying “shush up.
I’m still like, “Shush up and dance with me."
You know, I just…
I can’t say it.
It’s rude.
But we couldn’t say “butt".
I used it twice there, but one of them had two T’s.
We could use the conjunction;
the conjunction was allowed,
but we couldn’t… two T’s,
four letter word. Too far
That’s when it was done.
Which is ridiculous,
it was hard to tell stories without saying “butt".
Sometimes it’s easier to say “butt".
I was talking about a time I was sledding.
I was like, “Dad, we went sledding.
But, guess what, the sled broke
so we just kept sliding down the hill on our butt."
My dad, “Whoa! What happened there?
You forgot who you were."
“Okay, fine dad. I sledded down the hill on my bum.

Do you hear how
stupid that sounds?”
Sounds like I’m sliding down the hill on a homeless man
that I own for some reason.
Come on Gus, let’s go.
I’m gonna slide down the hill on ya, you’re my bum.
Here we go, I’ll hold ya.
My dad, “We don’t say bum either,
because that’s weird
what you did with your homeless friend there.

You slid down the hill on your
homeless friend,
not on your bum.
That’s rude.
Also, why do you have homeless friends?
You’re a lousy friend.
He should stay the night or something."
I didn’t know what to say.
I was like, “Fine, okay.
In our house we can’t say butt. We can’t say bum.
What can we say?”
My dad thinks about it,
“We can say bim. We’ll say bim. How about that?”
“No, that’s a weird made-up word, dad.
It’s not a real word, it makes us sound
like we’re a British family or something.
I slid down the hill on me bim father!
What a great day.

I slid all the way to the bim of the hill,"
we couldn’t say bottom either.
It’s rule after rule.
It’s ridiculous.
